oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Descriptive Epidemiology of Udder Cleft Dermatitis in a Dairy Herd with Sarcoptic Mange
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Warnick, L. D.
Nydam, D. V.
Maciel, A. E.
Guard, C. L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Udder rot
lesions
periparturient edema
mite infestation
sarcoptic mange
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Udder rot, or intertrigo of the udder, is characterized by foul-smelling, necrotic lesions between the lateral udder and medial thigh or between the halves of the udder. The etiology is unknown, but suspected causes include periparturient edema and mite infestation. The purpose of our study was to describe the occurrence of udder cleft dermatitis in a dairy herd experiencing an outbreak of sarcoptic mange.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2001; 138-139
